subject: Re: Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: ... Yes, they would; some words will look funny . And in some, the only vowel will be the letter Roe. But this is not unprecedented. The recent proposal for
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "paulhtremblay" <phthenry@...>
wrote:
>This may be a good idea, but that does mean that the words "earth and
>"early" would be spelled, respectively,
>
>Roar Thoth
>Roar Loll Eat (or If)
>

Yes, they would; some words will look "funny". And in some, the only
vowel will be the letter Roe. But this is not unprecedented. The
recent proposal for Ing would have "sing" as See+Ing. And even the
original rules in the QM have "being" as Bay-Ing, that's not an
abbreviations mind you, but the rules themselves concerning how to
handle -ing ending.

Also, there is no vowel sound that leaps easily to mind at the start
of "earth". Utter is an arbitrary choice, the letter Et could have
been chosen just as well, they both bare little resemblance to /3/.
And consider how a child instinctively starts the word "earth" not
with a any vowel at all but with the letter r.


>
>In order for this rule to work, I assume that the Earth
>sound is never followed by another vowel?
>

It would help to recognize which role Roe is playing in a
word but it wouldn't be critical for the rule to work.


>
>It also seems that we are
>shifting too much on to Roar now
>

Roe would be loaded with two sounds: /r\/ and /3/. But this is at
least better than overloading a *pair* of letters in the same way. I
mean Utter+Roe have two interpretations as it stands which I think is
a significantly messier arrangement than just shifting that burden to
a single letter.

Finally, the proposed additional sound for Roe is one people already
think Roe has: point to the letter Roe and ask someone to make that
sound and they will say "er".

But this proposal is a contradiction to the QMs example for the
word "hurt" and as such it should have a high hurdle for acceptance.

Having a new letter for the NURSE lexical set that bares a passing
resemblance to the Utter+Roe "ligature" is quite rational of course.
But adding a new letter is a horrendous undertaking to be avoided if
at all possible. It's certainly a much bigger deviation from the QM
than just putting NURSE with Roe. And after such a letter were made,
it would logical have to sit right next to Roe alphabetically anyway;
it'd be quite silly to tack it after all the vowels or shove it
between Loch and the Xs.


The choices at the moment seem to be:
1. endure the ambiguous reading of Utter+Roe
2. add the NURSE set to Roe
3. make a new letter for NURSE




>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Anthony Grahn" <othermale@>
> wrote:
> >
>
> > But in this case we do derive a very real benefit. The assigning of
> > NURSE to the letter pair Utter+Roe is causing tangle problems. As it
> > stands the letter pair Utter+Roe now has two separate sounds. It is
> > simpler to instead have a single letter with two separate sounds. In
> > this case Roe is a fair candidate especially since the sounds in
> > question [3] and [r\] are already pretty closely associated in peoples
> > minds. Thus while contrary to the QM, the benefit is comparable to the
> > It/Eat + Ing simplification.
> >
>
> This may be a good idea, but that does mean that the words "earth and
> "early" would be spelled, respectively,
>
> Roar Thoth
> Roar Loll Eat (or If)
>
> It seems a little funny to see Roar followed by another consonant in
> these cases. In order for this rule to work, I assume that the Earth
> sound is never followed by another vowel? It also seems that we are
> shifting too much on to Roar now. When coming upon a Roar, we are
> going to have to decide if it means Earth or Roar.
>
> Paul
>
